Rand Paul and Marco Rubio take shots over Cuba

Politics

Joseph Gerth, Louisville 3:33 p.m. EST December 19, 2014

U.S. Sens. Marco Rubio and Rand Paul.(Photo: Courier-Journal photo illustration.)

Tags

  • Rand Paul
  • U.S. Senate
  • Marco Rubio
20 CONNECT 6 TWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE

The 50-year-old cold war between the United States and Cuba has turned into a shooting war -- between a couple of Republican members of the U.S. Senate who disagree over whether relations with the island nation should be normalized.

Over the past few days, the battlefield has moved from radio to television and now to Facebook and Twitter, where U.S. Sen. Rand Paul spent the day Friday taunting Sen. Marco Rubio, the son of Cuban immigrants, who steadfastly opposes giving the Castro government more standing.

Senator @marcorubio is acting like an isolationist who wants to retreat to our borders and perhaps build a moat. I reject this isolationism.

— Senator Rand Paul (@SenRandPaul) December 19, 2014

The bruhaha began earlier in the week when Paul said he was open to President Obama's plan to begin normalizing relations with the country.

The U.S. and Cuba have been at odds since the late 1950s when Cuban rebels overthrew the government of Fulgencio Batista. It put an embargo in place in 1962 when the Fidel Castro government took up with the Soviet Union after the U.S. rebuffed Castro's overtures.

Obama can't lift the embargo without Congressional approval but he has put in motion steps to opening dialogue with the country. The moves were announced this week following discussions between the two countries that were helped along by the Vatican and after the countries returned prisoners they were each holding.

Paul, who harbors presidential ambitions, on Thursday broke with Republicans and suggested that opening dialogue with Cuba was "probably a good idea" and that the embargo policy has failed.

On a West Virginia radio station, Paul said, "If the goal is regime change, it sure doesn't seem to be working and probably it punishes the people more than the regime because the regime can blame the embargo for hardship."

Rubio, who is also mentioned as a possible 2016 presidential contender shot back on Fox News later in the day, saying that Paul was speaking from a position of ignorance.

"Like many people who have been opining, he has no idea what he's talking about," Rubio said.

That set the stage for a series of tweets and Facebook posts on Friday.

Hey @marcorubio if the embargo doesn't hurt Cuba, why do you want to keep it?

— Senator Rand Paul (@SenRandPaul) December 19, 2014

And then there was:

The United States trades and engages with other communist nations, such as China and Vietnam. So @marcorubio why not Cuba?

— Senator Rand Paul (@SenRandPaul) December 19, 2014

And just for good measure:

.@marcorubio what about the majority of Cuban-Americans who now support normalizing relations between our countries? http://t.co/0qhSOeD9Va

— Senator Rand Paul (@SenRandPaul) December 19, 2014

And he got more personal in a Facebook post referencing his family:

Post by RandPaul.

Rubio hasn't responded. Yet.
